datafield.subfield: Analysis and compensation of synchronous measurement error for multi-channel laser interferometer

Dual-frequency laser interferometer has been widely used in precision motion system as a displacement sensor, to achieve nanoscale positioning or synchronization accuracy. In a multi-channel laser interferometer synchronous measurement system, signal delays are different in the different channels, which will cause asynchronous measurement, and then lead to measurement error, synchronous measurement error (SME). Based on signal delay analysis of the measurement system, this paper presents a multi-channel SME framework for synchronous measurement, and establishes the model between SME and motion velocity. Further, a real-time compensation method for SME is proposed. This method has been verified in a self-developed laser interferometer signal processing board (SPB). The experiment result showed that, using this compensation method, at a motion velocity 0.89 m s(−)(1), the max SME between two measuring channels in the SPB is 1.1 nm. This method is more easily implemented and applied to engineering than the method of directly testing smaller signal delay.

Sources of time synchronization errorIn the laser interferometer system, signal delays include optical signal delay, electric signal delay and signal processing delay. As shown in figure, 3: #mstaa5f0cf03, optical signals are transmitted through air and optical fiber, and received by photoelectric converters, which convert the optical signals into electrical signals and send the signals to SPB. The speed of light va in air and optical fiber are nearly a same constant, va = c/n, c is 3\times {{10}^{8}} m s-1, n denotes the refractive index of the optical fiber and air, so the optical signal transfer delay denoted as {{\tau}_{od}}, is proportional to optical path \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{{\tau}_{od}}=\left({{l}_{a}}+{{l}_{f}}\right)/{{v}_{a}}={{k}_{od}}\left({{l}_{a}}+{{l}_{f}}\right)\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 5 } \end{equation*} where kod is the scale factor, la is the transmission length in air and lf is the transmission length in optical fiber. Clearly, {{\tau}_{od}} is independent of signal frequency. So, {{\tau}_{od}} is a constant in a certain measurement system. Meanwhile, for a measurement system, its signal processing (including data processing) delay is also a constant, denoted as {{\tau}_{rd}}.The electric signal delay is mainly caused in cables and SPB. As the cable is a certain length in system, the former are constant, according to Electromagnetic transmission principle [, 18: #mstaa5f0cbib018]. But in SPB, the electric signal delay is not constant. Because there are many capacitors, inductors, gates switch and integrated chips. Their impedances are related with signal frequency, and will lead to signal delay. However it is rather difficult to get an accurate model between delay and signal frequency. Considering that the frequencies of the reference signal, measurement signal and sampling signal are megahertz-order, belonging to high frequency signal, the relationship between the signal frequency and the delay is established as the following function in this paper, which is \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{{\tau}_{ed}}={{k}_{ed}}/f+m\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 6 } \end{equation*} where {{\tau}_{ed}} denotes the electric signal delay in SPB, f is signal frequency, ked is scale factor and m is a delay constant.
